habitat: Mycorrhizal with trees (especially deciduous) in forests and meadows across Europe and western Asia in late summer and autumn.
shortDescription: Highly poisonous, psychoactive mushroom with a brown-tan cap covered in white warts. Contains muscimol and ibotenic acid.
benefitsOrToxicity: Highly poisonous, containing muscimol and ibotenic acid. Causes hallucinations, confusion, seizures, and can be fatal. Some research suggests potential therapeutic benefits of muscimol.

identification.cap: 3-18 cm wide, convex to flat, sticky, brown to tan with small white warts.
identification.gills: Mostly free from the stem, white, crowded.
identification.stem: 4-20 cm long, up to 2.5 cm thick, tapering upward with a swollen base. White, with a skirt-like ring.
identification.flesh: White, does not change color when cut.

medicinalProperties: Research suggests muscimol may reduce stress, relieve pain, support sleep, and have anti-tumor properties.
note: First described by De Candolle in 1815 as Agaricus pantherinus, renamed by Kummer in 1871. The name 'pantherina' refers to its spotted cap. Used in various psychoactive products.
